<@U0UETGCJU>: We have moved to Firebase crash reporting.  It is part of there free package and a pretty good product.  It also plays nicely with the other Firebase products.  We used Crittersism before and it was also good on the free tier.  We weren’t interested in the other value adds they have so for us Firebase Crash reporting is the winner.
<@U1CV5DAMT>: even better than Fabric?
just found this comparison article .. reading it <https://medium.com/google-developer-experts/firebase-crash-reporting-vs-crashlytics-a6c287c4b792#.lpgcp321c>

attachments.title: Firebase Crash Reporting VS Crashlytics — Google Developer Experts
attachments.fallback: Medium: Firebase Crash Reporting VS Crashlytics — Google Developer Experts

text: I haven’t worked worked with Fabric and I’m sure they offer a pretty decent product but I would rather go with Firebase that has the backing of Google/Android.  It is still very new and in the MVP stage of development but this seems to be a product that Google is investing in so IMHO in the future it will have a better value proposition than the competitors.

also, firebase crash reporting is beta so that’s an important metric before choosing. I have used Crashlytics and know many companies using it with millions of active users and it does offer the value.
fabric is also good even i prefer firebase
never used firebase but used fabric
and its so reliable

another considerable thing could be how many methods count each is adding. Crashlytics adds 3277 <http://www.methodscount.com/?lib=com.crashlytics.sdk.android%3Acrashlytics%3A2.5.5> but no idea about firebase. anyone? :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U1U643L7Q>: 
com.google.firebase:firebase-crash:9.2.1 adds 207 methods
my bad. found it <http://www.methodscount.com/?lib=com.google.firebase%3Afirebase-crash%3A%2B>
<@U1CV5DAMT>: but we should consider Methods count or total count?
I would say method count to avoid multidex. the other is line count I think which to me would not make to much difference.

I think in the end of the day the differences between the various prod crash tracking provider are very small in comparison to not having any prod crash tracking solution.  So <@U0UETGCJU> I would say go with your gut if you are on the free tier and if you don’t like it change it.  They are normally very easy to implement.
absolutely agree!
<@U1U643L7Q>: I was wrong total count is Lib method count + dependancy method count.  17K for Firebase seems quite high but I wonder how much would be removed through proguard
yes … thanks for responding on that :slightly_smiling_face: that was also my concern. The different is huge.
I've just had to reduce an app down that had 93k methods

Got it to 47.5k before I started putting libraries back in that we need (like RxJava)... Now sitting at 52,5k, reckon I can get below the 50k mark again soon removing some of the other libraries the original dev used for things he should be able to code himself
<@U1LJG0Y03>: are you using proguard?
great discussion guys thanks very much
<@U1CV5DAMT>: minify is disabled at the moment, will be messing about with that soon, aiming at getting the hard count down for now
Problem is I'm not exactly experienced in optimising the gradle :stuck_out_tongue: Learning that atm
Can anyone link me some good resources on gradle btw?
^ I'm with this guy
build types, flavors, env. variables, etc.
if there's a well known place for that I'd be happy to be made aware of :slightly_smiling_face:
here is a gradle course <https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/ud867>

text: <@U1SKM4BGV>: a custom preference view would be the way to go
to avoid app compatibility issue and many more other issue better to make it as custom preference look alike activity..
any OkHttp gurus here?
I’ve got a backend that accepts a POST request with a body
if I send `{}` as a body, everything’s fine
it hangs
the backend
I use Retrofit as my rest api library
and Gson for json
and the back end?
yeah, no idea
sounds like a back end error
yeah, I guess it is

the actual problem is the following: I’ve got a complex object with multiple fields. if its json representation exceeds some length, then the server hangs as if I added a new line somewhere in the json (like the example above)
<@U0B6XQJ2F>: obviously in reality you are not going to send an empty object.  What does it do when you send a non empty object?
does it do the same when using curl?
nope
I use Postman though, but it’s the same
if I send an unformatted object, it works
if I add a new line anywhere, it doesn’t work
are you sending the content-type header?
let me see
yeah, it’s `application/json`
it’s obviously a backend problem, but I would want to know why OkHttp/GsonConverter adds a new line someplace
I don’t see it in the logs though, the new line
I see that is sends `Content-Length: 802` in the headers, and the body in the logs is 802 in length too

for anyone curious - the problem was no in the new-line (OkHttp/GsonConverter wasn’t adding one). the problem was with double different field that was encoded as `75.0` instead of `75` and the backend can’t parse it for some reason

Hi, I have a query related to build flavors. We currently have 2 flavors, say flavor A and flavor B. The 2 of them can work in conjunction, so I could have them installed on the same phone at the same time. We now want to add a 3rd flavor flavor C. But the way it would work is that flavor C can work in conjunction with flavor A, just like flavor B. But it cannot run in conjunction with flavor B. Is something like this possible?
The only difference between flavor B and flavor C is that flavor B is a signed apk whereas flavor C is not signed. But both run the same code and use the same set of proguard rules
all apks are signed, if you don’t specify they just get signed by your debug certificate
I don’t understand exactly why you’d want to do something like that

<@U053PPGDC>: yeah i just realised that, makes sense. Stupid of me to think of that. A simple way to state the reason would be that there is data on our production server which is dummy/testing data. We want to be able to track in our analytics that this data created by this user was solely for testing and it should not be counted for when pulling real numbers from our analytics data. So I was wondering if a new build flavor is a solution to this problem, even though it personally feels like an overkill
- your prod server shouldn’t have dummy/test data
<@U053PPGDC>: yeah tell that to our server guys
:joy:
guys it would be great help if anyone have the solution
<@U053PPGDC>: I am junior-ish developer. So its kinda tough to influence people into understanding the pain.....something along those lines
sure.
can you have a solution where you just make sure your testing data starts with test_ or something similar
simple behaviour change can go a long way :wink:
<@U053PPGDC>: That is definitely elegant. But the way our product works, our end users have the freedom to use test_whatever and use the app
guys...:frowning:
